item.title: Hamas says Israel killing commander threatens ceasefire

item.title: Pope Leo calls for end to violence in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description:
During the Sunday Angelus Pope Leo appeals for those fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo to stop the violence which has broken out and return to constructive dialogue. item.title: Pope Leo: Flowers can bloom even in prisons
item.description:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
During his homily on the Sunday of the Jubilee of Prisoners, Pope Leo XIV challenges both inmates and those responsible for the prisons to hold on to hope and he reminds everyone “that no human being is defined only by his or her actions and that justice is always a process of reparation and reconciliation.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-with-mercy-forgiveness-flowers-can-bloom-even-in-prisons.html)

item.title: Challenging period ahead as flu season gathers pace
item.description: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. The flu this winter has come a few weeks early and is mainly being driven by a mutated A(H3N2) virus. Seasons that start early, tend to be more severe.
item.source:markdown: Ireland has experienced bad influenza seasons before, and the weeks ahead are shaping up to offer a testing season of festive flu and colds. The flu this winter has come a few weeks early and is mainly being driven by a mutated A(H3N2) virus. Seasons that start early, tend to be more severe.

item.title: A year of 'dramatic highs and lows': 2025's 'roller-coaster ride' for the Royals
item.description: In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.
item.source:markdown:
![A person standing talks to a person seated in an elaborate chair, with a Canadian flag between them.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/10bf0528-3921-4d36-aba0-6c22dc685fbc,1765568073318/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7856%2C4419%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
In the annals of Royal Family history, 2025 will be remembered as the year the monarch took the virtually unprecedented step of stripping his younger brother of his titles and honours. But as much as the scandal surrounding the former prince now known only as Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor garnered headlines, there were other notable moments this year that sent signals about the monarchy and its future.

item.title: Pope: The Nativity is a gift of light for our world in need of hope
item.description:
Speaking to about 1,000 people taking part in the “Living Nativity” tradition at the Basilica of St. Mary Major, Pope Leo challenges them to spread the message that we are never alone and continue to be “pilgrims of hope, bearers of consolation and inspiration for all those you meet.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:

[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-12/pope-to-living-nativity-participants-a-gift-of-light-for-world.html)

item.title: 2 killed in Russia, millions in Ukraine without power as energy infrastructure targeted
item.description: At least two people were killed in a drone attack in Russia’s southwestern Saratov region, and parts of Ukraine went without power following targeted assaults on energy infrastructure, local authorities said Saturday, as U.S.-led peace talks on ending the war press on.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors debate deepening crisis in eastern DR Congo
item.description: The UN Security Council meet this morning in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. The UN Peacekeeping chief briefed on recent peace efforts – including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again – heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council meet this morning in New York to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid intensified fighting and mass displacement. The UN Peacekeeping chief briefed on recent peace efforts – including the Washington Accords between the DRC and Rwanda, signed just days before violence surged again – heightening fears of a worsening humanitarian emergency and regional spillover. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. Find our recent reporting here on the crisis and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

item.title: UN mission’s exit marks milestone in Iraq’s post-conflict transition
item.description: After more than two decades working alongside Iraq through war, political upheaval and the fight against ISIL terrorists, the UN Assistance Mission there (UNAMI) ends its mandate on 31 December – a closure its top official describes as “honourable, dignified, and earned”.

item.title: Venezuela vexes Trump but rightward trend across Americas could help U.S. national security strategy
item.description: The favourite in Chile's election on Sunday is the right-wing José Antonio Kast. A Kast victory would be the latest rightward political shift in South America, as U.S. President Donald Trump and the White House try to coax or force the socialist leader of Venezuela from office.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Maestro Riccardo Muti set to conduct concert in Vatican
item.description:
On 12 December, world-renowned conductor Riccardo Muti performs with the Luigi Cherubini Youth Orchestra and the Choir of the Siena Cathedral “Guido Chigi Saracini” in the Vatican's Paul VI Hall. During the occasion, Muti will receive the prestigious "Ratzinger Prize," established in 2011, and awarded annually, with the Pope's approval, to eminent personalities in the field of Christian-inspired culture and art.

item.source:markdown:

item.description: Gaza’s health system for mothers and newborns has been “decimated”, the UN said on Thursday, with Israeli attacks destroying almost all hospitals, cutting off medical supplies and driving sharp rises in maternal deaths, miscarriages and newborn fatalities amid mass displacement and hunger.

item.title: WHO expert group reaffirms no link between vaccines and autism
item.description: A World Health Organization (WHO) expert committee has again confirmed that there is no causal link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD), following a new review of global scientific evidence.
item.source:markdown: A World Health Organization (WHO) expert committee has again confirmed that there is no causal link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD), following a new review of global scientific evidence.

item.title: Venezuela’s National Guard linked to killings, torture and repression, UN probe finds
item.description: Venezuela’s Bolivarian National Guard (GNB) has been implicated in a decade-long pattern of killings, arbitrary detentions, torture and sexual violence targeting protesters and opponents of President Nicolás Maduro, according to a new report from UN-appointed investigators on Thursday.
item.source:markdown: Venezuela’s Bolivarian National Guard (GNB) has been implicated in a decade-long pattern of killings, arbitrary detentions, torture and sexual violence targeting protesters and opponents of President Nicolás Maduro, according to a new report from UN-appointed investigators on Thursday.

item.title: UN warns of ‘regional conflagration’ as DR Congo violence uproots 500,000
item.description: More than half a million people have now been uprooted by escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) the UN said on Thursday, warning that the M23 rebel offensive is driving a rapidly worsening humanitarian emergency.
item.source:markdown: More than half a million people have now been uprooted by escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) the UN said on Thursday, warning that the M23 rebel offensive is driving a rapidly worsening humanitarian emergency.

item.title: Can dialogue heal a fractured world? A UN-led alliance is making the case
item.description: As 2025 draws to a close, geopolitical divides are deepening – North and South, East and West. Against this backdrop, the UN Alliance of Civilizations marks two decades of bridging divides as its Riyadh Forum takes on intolerance, hate speech, and the fight for mutual respect in a multipolar world.

item.title: Iceland will boycott Eurovision in protest of Israel's participation
item.description: Spain, the Netherlands, Ireland and Slovenia have also announced their plans to boycott the event, citing Israel's conduct in its war against Hamas in Gaza. This comes after the European Broadcasting Union, made up of a number of European public broadcasters, cleared Israel to participate last week.

item.title: Is Trump’s stark new security strategy the end of the liberal world order? Europeans will need convincing
item.description: European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. item.title: Venezuela's Machado defies travel ban, arrives in Oslo to claim Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: After more than a year mostly spent in hiding and in defiance of a decade-long travel ban,  Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado arrived in Norway on Thursday, hours after a ceremony to award her the Nobel Peace Prize. Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a dress with a slight smile is shown standing behind a podium on a stage.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/e5d745ec-9f14-43ab-b179-d17843cf3146,1765380310224/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C4526%2C2545%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After more than a year mostly spent in hiding and in defiance of a decade-long travel ban, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado arrived in Norway on Thursday, hours after a ceremony to award her the Nobel Peace Prize. Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela.

item.title: What’s happening between Thailand and Cambodia?

item.title: Architecture is art — without it ‘you're giving up’: rebel architect Frank Gehry
item.description: Toronto-born architect Frank Gehry has died at 96. A rebel in his field, who never hid his disdain for the media, granted IDEAS producer Mary Lynk a rare opportunity in 2017 to spend a couple of days with him at his studio in Los Angeles. This conversation is a two-part series that delves into Gehry's infusion of humanity into his designs.
item.source:markdown:
![An older man is outside under a blue sky looking up with buildings surrounding him in the background](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/50a206e0-0e1e-49e8-9259-4cc4949b2e4f,1765233589323/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C656%2C6305%2C3546%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Toronto-born architect Frank Gehry has died at 96. A rebel in his field, who never hid his disdain for the media, granted IDEAS producer Mary Lynk a rare opportunity in 2017 to spend a couple of days with him at his studio in Los Angeles. This conversation is a two-part series that delves into Gehry's infusion of humanity into his designs.

item.title: Ukraine faces freezing winter under fire as UN warns of rising civilian toll

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet over rising civilian deaths in Ukraine
item.description: The Security Council is meeting in New York for a high-stakes briefing on Ukraine, called by six members amid rising civilian casualties and renewed strikes on energy infrastructure as winter sets in. It comes as Washington’s 28-point peace proposal is being revised following pushback from Kyiv and European allies, and after talks in Moscow and Florida failed to deliver concrete progress. Today’s meeting will gauge where diplomacy stands. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council is meeting in New York for a high-stakes briefing on Ukraine, called by six members amid rising civilian casualties and renewed strikes on energy infrastructure as winter sets in. It comes as Washington’s 28-point peace proposal is being revised following pushback from Kyiv and European allies, and after talks in Moscow and Florida failed to deliver concrete progress. Today’s meeting will gauge where diplomacy stands. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.

item.description: From salt made by hand on a Philippine island, to ceremonial dances in Kenya and ancient textile traditions in Belarus, the UN cultural agency has added a diverse range of living traditions to its global lists of culture at risk, highlighting both the richness of expression and the urgent need to safeguard heritage.

item.title: Record number of Irish whiskey cases sold last year
item.description: A record number of cases of Irish whiskey were sold last year. The latest Irish Whiskey Global Trade Report shows that 16.15 million cases, which each contain 12 bottles, were purchased in 2024.

item.title: 2025 on track to tie second hottest year on record

item.title: See the moment a Hawaii volcano's eruption knocked out a remote camera
item.description: A remote camera on Hawaii's erupting Kīlauea volcano captured the moment a lava fountain engulfed it and knocked it offline on Saturday. Kilauea, one of the world's most active volcanoes, has been erupting intermittently since Dec. 23, 2024.
item.source:markdown:
![A composite image showing a volcanic eruption on the left and debris and smoke filling the frame on the right.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/06a4ef60-4b06-4fda-b323-ba4de53f3749,1765246824893/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Man who machine-gunned family member convicted of murder
item.description: A gunman who said he was "shovelling" cocaine into himself when he opened fire on a family member with a submachine gun in the victim's front garden was not suffering from a "substance-induced psychotic disorder", a jury has found in unanimously convicting him of murder.
item.source:markdown: A gunman who said he was "shovelling" cocaine into himself when he opened fire on a family member with a submachine gun in the victim's front garden was not suffering from a "substance-induced psychotic disorder", a jury has found in unanimously convicting him of murder.

item.title: One in seven homes sell for at least 20% over ask price

item.title: Dept says aims for effective use of asylum accommodation

item.title: Thousands of Santas dash through Liverpool streets for charity
item.description: Liverpool's annual Santa Dash made spirits bright on Sunday as thousands of runners dressed as Santa Claus took to the streets of the English city for the five-kilometre festive fun run. Participants are encouraged to raise money for local charities as part of the event, which began in 2004.

item.title: Trump's new security strategy aligns with Russia's interests, Kremlin says
item.description: The Kremlin on Sunday welcomed U.S. President Donald Trump's new national security strategy and said it largely accorded with Russia's own perceptions, the first time that Moscow has so fulsomely praised such a document from its former Cold War foe.

item.title: US says deal to end Ukraine war 'really close'

item.title: ‘The system has failed’: Giles Duley’s mission to reframe disability in war
item.description: Talking to journalists earlier this week on his final day as the first UN Global Advocate for Persons with Disabilities in Conflict and Peacebuilding Situations, Giles Duley said he felt he had failed in his core mission. More importantly, he added, the system itself has failed.
item.source:markdown: Talking to journalists earlier this week on his final day as the first UN Global Advocate for Persons with Disabilities in Conflict and Peacebuilding Situations, Giles Duley said he felt he had failed in his core mission. More importantly, he added, the system itself has failed.

item.title: Review after couple wrongly advised of fatal abnormality
item.description: The CEO of the HSE has issued an "unequivocal" apology on behalf of the organisation and has said an independent review will take place into the case of a couple who agreed to have a termination after being wrongly advised that their healthy baby boy had a fatal foetal abnormality.
item.source:markdown: The CEO of the HSE has issued an "unequivocal" apology on behalf of the organisation and has said an independent review will take place into the case of a couple who agreed to have a termination after being wrongly advised that their healthy baby boy had a fatal foetal abnormality.

item.title: Five killed in Pakistan, Afghanistan border clashes
item.description: Pakistan and Afghanistan exchanged heavy fire along their border late last night, officials from both countries said, killing at least five people amid heightened tensions following failed peace talks last weekend.

item.title: Russia unleashes massive drone and missile attack on Ukraine amid diplomatic talks
item.description: Russia unleashed a major missile and drone barrage on Ukraine overnight into Saturday, after U.S. and Ukrainian officials said they’ll meet on Saturday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the nearly four-year-old war.

Russia unleashed a major missile and drone barrage on Ukraine overnight into Saturday, after U.S. and Ukrainian officials said they’ll meet on Saturday for a third day of talks aimed at ending the nearly four-year-old war.

item.title: Chornobyl nuclear plant's protective shield damaged - UN
item.description: A protective shield at the Chornobyl nuclear plant in war-torn Ukraine, built to contain radioactive material from the 1986 disaster, can no longer perform its main safety function due to drone damage, the UN nuclear watchdog said, a strike Ukraine has attributed to Russia.

item.title: Elon Musk's X slapped with €120M fine by EU regulator for breaching content rules

item.title: Four plead guilty over attempt to import drugs worth €31m

item.title: Bishops of Mozambique gather for plenary assembly in Maputo as Cardinal Parolin visits
item.description:
The Episcopal Conference of Mozambique (CEM) has said that Cardinal Pietro Parolin will visit Mozambique this week. The visit is being seen as a gesture of reassurance and closeness by the Holy Father, Pope Leo XIV, given the ongoing insurgency in the restive Cabo Delgado Province. Attacks by Islamist militants have displaced thousands and caused the deaths of many innocent civilians. CEM’s plenary assembly will also take place during this period. Cardinal Parolin is expected to be in Mozambique

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Episcopal Conference of Mozambique (CEM) has said that Cardinal Pietro Parolin will visit Mozambique this week. The visit is being seen as a gesture of reassurance and closeness by the Holy Father, Pope Leo XIV, given the ongoing insurgency in the restive Cabo Delgado Province. Attacks by Islamist militants have displaced thousands and caused the deaths of many innocent civilians. CEM’s plenary assembly will also take place during this period. Cardinal Parolin is expected to be in Mozambique

item.title: Arab region pushed to limits by climate extremes as 2024 smashes heat records
item.description: The Arab region is heating at nearly twice the global average, UN weather experts warned on Thursday, after 2024 saw unprecedented heat, destructive storms and worsening water scarcity impact some of the world’s most vulnerable communities.

item.title: UN and partners back new measures to help millions move from vulnerability to opportunity
item.description: A major UN meeting in Doha wrapped up on Thursday with a renewed drive to help the world’s poorest countries move towards long-term stability and prosperity, as senior officials urged stronger global partnerships to ensure that development gains are not lost once States exit the Least Developed Country (LDC) category.

item.title: Deadly storms sweep South and Southeast Asia, leaving over 1,600 dead
item.description: From Sri Lanka’s central highlands to Indonesia’s flood-swollen river basins, a wave of climate-fuelled cyclones and monsoon rains has unleashed one of the deadliest weather patterns south and southeast Asia has seen in years, killing more than 1,600 people, displacing hundreds of thousands and affecting millions.
item.source:markdown: From Sri Lanka’s central highlands to Indonesia’s flood-swollen river basins, a wave of climate-fuelled cyclones and monsoon rains has unleashed one of the deadliest weather patterns south and southeast Asia has seen in years, killing more than 1,600 people, displacing hundreds of thousands and affecting millions.

item.title: Trump offered Putin a tactical victory in Ukraine. It wasn’t enough

item.title: Colombian president warns against attacking sovereignty

item.title: Israel says it received remains from Gaza that Hamas says belongs to missing hostage
item.description: Israel received a body on Wednesday that Hamas said was one of the last two deceased hostages in the Gaza Strip. It comes as Israel said it would allow Gaza's gateway to Egypt to open once all hostages were returned.

Israel received a body on Wednesday that Hamas said was one of the last two deceased hostages in the Gaza Strip. It comes as Israel said it would allow Gaza's gateway to Egypt to open once all hostages were returned.

item.title: Deep-sea search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to resume
item.description: Malaysia's transport ministry said Wednesday that the deep-sea hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will resume Dec. 30, renewing hopes of finally locating the jet that vanished without a trace more than a decade ago.
item.source:markdown:
![A group of people, seated in chairs, look distressed. One woman holds her hand to her forehead, crying.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/a43fd6a7-ff24-47ea-9e8c-c20e11987a6b,1764749054252/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C415%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Malaysia's transport ministry said Wednesday that the deep-sea hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will resume Dec. 30, renewing hopes of finally locating the jet that vanished without a trace more than a decade ago.

item.title: Russia says no compromise reached in peace talks with US
item.description: Russia and the US did not reach a compromise on a possible peace deal to end the war in Ukraine after a five-hour meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump's top envoys, the Kremlin has said.
item.source:markdown: Russia and the US did not reach a compromise on a possible peace deal to end the war in Ukraine after a five-hour meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump's top envoys, the Kremlin has said.

item.title: Will a fishing boat spark a crisis between China and Japan? | About That
item.description: Tensions between China and Japan are rising over Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's recent comments on Taiwan, combined with a long-standing dispute over a chain of uninhabited islands. Andrew Chang breaks down why these tiny islands are so valuable, how Taiwan factors in and how this dispute has pushed two of Asia's biggest powers to a tipping point. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images
item.source:markdown:
![Map highlighting China, Taiwan, and Japan's locations. The text "Fishing boat standoff" appears next to Taiwan, with China and Japan labeled.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/4b6f17a7-f8b9-42bb-8ef7-92326304c295,1764726155741/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Tensions between China and Japan are rising over Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's recent comments on Taiwan, combined with a long-standing dispute over a chain of uninhabited islands. Andrew Chang breaks down why these tiny islands are so valuable, how Taiwan factors in and how this dispute has pushed two of Asia's biggest powers to a tipping point. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: Pope: ‘I was thinking of retiring, but instead I surrendered to God’
item.description:
Aboard the papal plane returning to Rome from Lebanon, Pope Leo XIV speaks to journalists about the role of the Holy See, which works “behind-the-scenes” in peace negotiations, so that all parties may lay down arms. Regarding Ukraine, the Pope underlines Europe’s involvement and the important role Italy could play, and answers a question about how he reacted to his election, stressing the importance of giving one’s life to God and letting him "lead the way".

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.description: The Prada Group closed the purchase of Milan fashion rival Versace in a $1.375 billion US ($1.93 billion Cdn) cash deal that puts the fashion house known for its sexy silhouettes under the same roof as Prada's "ugly chic" aesthetic and Miu Miu's youth-driven appeal.

item.title: Serena Williams shuts down talk of a tennis comeback
item.description: Serena Williams threw cold water on the idea that she might be preparing to return to tennis, saying Tuesday that she is "NOT coming back," after a spokesman for the International Tennis Integrity Agency (ITIA) said the 23-time Grand Slam champion had registered with the sport's drug-testing body.

Former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, sentenced last year to 45 years in prison for his role in a drug-trafficking operation that moved hundreds of tonnes of cocaine to the United States, was released from prison following a pardon from President Donald Trump, officials confirmed Tuesday.

item.title: Pope Leo at Beirut farewell: 'Choose peace as a way, not just a goal'
item.description:

item.title: Concern bluetongue will spread in spring if not contained
item.description: The Chair of Medicines at Veterinary Ireland has said that if a suspected outbreak of bluetongue in Northern Ireland is not contained, it could spread during fly season late next spring and early summer.
item.source:markdown: The Chair of Medicines at Veterinary Ireland has said that if a suspected outbreak of bluetongue in Northern Ireland is not contained, it could spread during fly season late next spring and early summer.

item.title: Irish films triumph at British Independent Film Awards
item.description: The Irish-produced films Pillion and My Father's Shadow triumphed at the British Independent Film Awards on Sunday, while Donegal filmmaker Myrid Carten recieved three awards for her acclaimed debut feature A Want In Her.
item.source:markdown: The Irish-produced films Pillion and My Father's Shadow triumphed at the British Independent Film Awards on Sunday, while Donegal filmmaker Myrid Carten recieved three awards for her acclaimed debut feature A Want In Her.

item.title: More than 5,000 people being granted Irish citizenship
item.description: Irish citizenship is to be granted to some 5,200 people at ceremonies today and tomorrow in Co Kerry.
item.source:markdown: Irish citizenship is to be granted to some 5,200 people at ceremonies today and tomorrow in Co Kerry.

item.title: Hong Kong highrise netting did not meet code, officials say, with death toll at 151 people
item.description: Hong Kong officials said Monday that their investigation into a deadly blaze that killed at least 151 people has revealed some of the netting that covered scaffolding used in renovations was not up to fire-safety codes, as a wave of public sympathy and support was met by government moves to stifle criticism.
item.source:markdown:
![The inside of a residence is shown, with damage to walls and floors. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/2c0182af-0d05-4cce-ba8f-065f7a7c64bd,1764587273866/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C290%2C4000%2C2250%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Hong Kong officials said Monday that their investigation into a deadly blaze that killed at least 151 people has revealed some of the netting that covered scaffolding used in renovations was not up to fire-safety codes, as a wave of public sympathy and support was met by government moves to stifle criticism.

item.title: 1897 go 2025: A look back at Oireachtas na Gaeilge
item.description: Oireachtas na Gaeilge dates back to 1897, when the Gaelic League - or as it is now called Conradh na Gaeilge - set up the event to organise a wide range of events to celebrate the Irish language and culture.

item.title: Kielty on the Toy Show: 'It's like Irish Thanksgiving'

item.title: Peace remains elusive for Lebanese Christians as Pope Leo visits war-torn country
item.description: On his first international trip as pontiff, Pope Leo XIV is carrying a message of unity and peace to the Middle East. Sunday in Lebanon, he challenged leaders to be true peacemakers and set aside their differences. It’s a precarious time in the country, which faces deep domestic political divisions and regular Israeli strikes in the south. Special correspondent Simona Foltyn reports. PBS News is supported by - https://www.pbs.org/newshour/about/funders. Hosted on Acast. See acast.com/privacy

item.title: Why does Trump keep berating female reporters?
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's recent remarks towards female journalists, including calling one 'piggy,' is renewing discussion about how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs. Industry experts suggest these incidents are 'an unmistakable pattern of hostility — often directed at women — that undermines the essential role of a free and independent press.'
item.source:markdown:
![US President Donald Trump berating female reporters. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ca4728b4-ee65-4dc0-adb8-2f5ccedb3d23,1764550304383/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C66%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump's recent remarks towards female journalists, including calling one 'piggy,' is renewing discussion about how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs. Industry experts suggest these incidents are 'an unmistakable pattern of hostility — often directed at women — that undermines the essential role of a free and independent press.'

item.title: Cyclone Ditwah brings worst flooding in decades to Sri Lanka, killing hundreds
item.description: Sri Lanka is facing one of its worst flood disasters in two decades, with nearly one million people affected and more than 400 reported dead or missing after Cyclone Ditwah unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across the island.

item.title: German Christmas markets open 1 year after deadly attack
item.description: Christmas markets are open in Germany with increased security this year. In 2024, a man drove an SUV into crowds at the Christmas market in the central city of Magdeburg, killing six. Freelance journalist Natalie Carney spoke to visitors at the Christmas market in Munich.

item.title: Indonesian residents hunt for food and water after deadly floods; 193 dead in Sri Lanka
item.description: Some residents of the flood-hit Indonesian island of Sumatra have resorted to stealing food and water to survive, authorities said Sunday, while Sri Lankan officials said deaths from floods and mudslides in that island nation have risen to 193.

item.title: Death toll in Hong Kong apartment complex blaze rises to 146 as the city mourns
item.description: The death toll in Hong Kong’s apartment complex  blaze rose to 146 on Sunday as investigators discovered more bodies in the burned-out buildings. A steady stream of people placed bouquets of flowers at an ever-growing makeshift memorial at the scene of the disaster, among the worst in the city’s history.
item.source:markdown:
![People kneel to deposit flowers with two towers covered in burnt scaffolding in the background.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/ad5cf993-a0c2-43f5-a317-2fb9a71f59e5,1764506670495/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C361%2C4500%2C2531%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The death toll in Hong Kong’s apartment complex blaze rose to 146 on Sunday as investigators discovered more bodies in the burned-out buildings. A steady stream of people placed bouquets of flowers at an ever-growing makeshift memorial at the scene of the disaster, among the worst in the city’s history.

item.title: Should kidfluencers be banned? That’s the plan in the EU
item.description: With the top kidfluencers in the world earning millions a year, leaders in the EU are worried the lure of lucrative sponsorship deals may tempt some parents to expliot their children in sponsored posts online. So this week, the EU announced plans to ban social media platforms from providing financial or material incentives for kidfluencing. Experts says Canada needs to come up with its own law.
item.source:markdown:
![A girl with blonde hair and a smaller girl with brown hair look at a table full of toy boxes for the line Millie and Friends Mouse in the House. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/69c4ee08-eb65-4b47-a46b-10d3113be42f,1764300156200/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C5%2C2361%2C1328%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
With the top kidfluencers in the world earning millions a year, leaders in the EU are worried the lure of lucrative sponsorship deals may tempt some parents to expliot their children in sponsored posts online. So this week, the EU announced plans to ban social media platforms from providing financial or material incentives for kidfluencing. Experts says Canada needs to come up with its own law.

item.title: Trump sent federal troops to 'save' Chicago. The 'Midway Blitz' raids forced the Windy City to defend itself
item.description: After the death of MAGA activist Charlie Kirk, U.S. President Donald Trump promised "to save Chicago" from crime and migrants. But in the wake of violent immigration raids, Chicagoans themselves are divided over who the criminals are — and who is ultimately responsible for keeping their city safe.
item.source:markdown:
![Demonstrators face off against rows of federal immigration enforcement agents.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b0caa8fa-b7f5-437a-ba4f-d364e5e0c314,1764351415388/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C310%2C5961%2C3353%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
After the death of MAGA activist Charlie Kirk, U.S. President Donald Trump promised "to save Chicago" from crime and migrants. But in the wake of violent immigration raids, Chicagoans themselves are divided over who the criminals are — and who is ultimately responsible for keeping their city safe.

item.title: Maduro slams 'colonial threat' as Trump says Venezuelan airspace should be closed
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump on Saturday said that the airspace "above and surrounding" Venezuela should be considered as "closed in its entirety," an assertion that raised more questions about the U.S. pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro. item.title: Orban defies EU by promising to keep buying Russian oil

item.title: Court rules Enoch Burke salary be paid directly to school

item.title: Zelensky's top aide resigns after anti-corruption raids
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's chief of staff Andriy Yermak, a close ally of the president who has headed Ukraine's negotiation team at fraught US-backed peace talks, has resigned, hours after anti-corruption agents searched his home.

item.title: Israeli forces kill at least 13 in southern Syria raid, officials and residents say
item.description: Israeli forces in southern Syria raided a village and opened fire when they were confronted by residents on Friday, killing at least 13, Syrian officials said, as Israel fights on a number of fronts while the shaky ceasefire in Gaza moves forward.
item.source:markdown:
![A man stands as he receives medical treatment at a hospital.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/60f468bf-bc7b-4068-9317-f93592d1c428,1764349740289/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C255%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Israeli forces in southern Syria raided a village and opened fire when they were confronted by residents on Friday, killing at least 13, Syrian officials said, as Israel fights on a number of fronts while the shaky ceasefire in Gaza moves forward.

item.title: UN chief condemns Guinea-Bissau coup, urges restoration of constitutional order
item.description: The United Nations has strongly condemned the military coup in Guinea-Bissau, warning that the overthrow of elected authorities just days after national elections represents a grave violation of constitutional order and democratic principles.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations has strongly condemned the military coup in Guinea-Bissau, warning that the overthrow of elected authorities just days after national elections represents a grave violation of constitutional order and democratic principles.

item.title: UN rights office condemns ‘apparent summary execution’ of two men in the West Bank
item.description: The UN human rights office, OHCHR said on Friday that it was “appalled” by the “brazen killing” of two Palestinian men by Israeli border police in the West Bank, describing it as “an apparent summary execution.”
item.source:markdown: The UN human rights office, OHCHR said on Friday that it was “appalled” by the “brazen killing” of two Palestinian men by Israeli border police in the West Bank, describing it as “an apparent summary execution.”

item.title: UN warns Myanmar’s planned elections will deepen repression and instability
item.description: Myanmar’s planned late-December elections are unfolding in what UN rights officials describe as an atmosphere of fear, violence and deep political repression, with thousands detained and major parties excluded in a process that risks entrenching instability rather than restoring democracy.
item.source:markdown: Myanmar’s planned late-December elections are unfolding in what UN rights officials describe as an atmosphere of fear, violence and deep political repression, with thousands detained and major parties excluded in a process that risks entrenching instability rather than restoring democracy.

item.title: Global measles cases surge as 30 million children miss vaccines, UN health agency warns
item.description: Measles deaths have dropped by 88 per cent since 2000 – yet an estimated 95,000 people, mostly children, still died from the virus last year, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Friday.
item.source:markdown: Measles deaths have dropped by 88 per cent since 2000 – yet an estimated 95,000 people, mostly children, still died from the virus last year, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Friday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Children hit by HIV funding gaps, risks to Pakistan’s courts, minority exclusion
item.description: Children and adolescents living with HIV continue to be left behind in access to early diagnosis, life-saving treatment and care, as shrinking funding threatens to reverse decades of progress, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) warned on Friday, ahead of World AIDS Day.

item.title: Ukraine presidential adviser Yermak resigns in another blow for Zelenskyy's government
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Friday that his chief of staff, Andriy Yermak, has submitted his resignation amid a corruption scandal. The departure comes at a perilous time for Kyiv as it faces U.S. pressure to make concessions to Moscow to end its war on Ukraine and lacks the soldiers or weapons to push Russian forces back.
item.source:markdown:
![Two bearded man are shown standing. One stares toward camera while wearing a suit and tie, while another, shorter man in a black top looks off to the side.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/60f69846-b1e3-4b31-980c-a76ef711e651,1764344705829/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C20%2C1946%2C1094%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Friday that his chief of staff, Andriy Yermak, has submitted his resignation amid a corruption scandal. The departure comes at a perilous time for Kyiv as it faces U.S. pressure to make concessions to Moscow to end its war on Ukraine and lacks the soldiers or weapons to push Russian forces back.

item.title: 'Violence against women is a men's problem', says Cairns
item.description: Social Democrats leader Holly Cairns has said violence against women is a "men's problem", adding that the problem will not be fully addressed until more men join the fight against it.

item.title: Somalia declares drought emergency as millions face hunger after failed rains
item.description: Somalia is facing a rapidly worsening drought emergency, with vast swaths of the country now parched after four failed rainy seasons, leaving millions at risk of hunger and displacement, UN humanitarians warned on Wednesday.
item.source:markdown: Somalia is facing a rapidly worsening drought emergency, with vast swaths of the country now parched after four failed rainy seasons, leaving millions at risk of hunger and displacement, UN humanitarians warned on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s children enter fourth school year under invasion as 4.6 million face education barriers
item.description: This year alone, 4.6 million children in Ukraine are struggling to access education as they endure a fourth academic year under full-scale war.
item.source:markdown: This year alone, 4.6 million children in Ukraine are struggling to access education as they endure a fourth academic year under full-scale war.

item.title: New prosecutor won't pursue charges against Trump in Georgia election interference case
item.description: A judge on Wednesday dismissed the Georgia election interference case against U.S. President Donald Trump and others after the prosecutor who took over the case said he would not pursue the charges, ending the last effort to prosecute Trump for his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss.

item.title: Hong Kong buildings blaze kills 44, nearly 300 missing

item.title: Prices of many tractors double amid material costs rise
item.description: The value of farm machinery to the Irish economy has reached €4.76 billion, according to the first ever economic report in the area, while a jump in raw material costs has contributed to the prices of many tractors doubling in the last decade.

item.title: F-35 beat Gripen fighter jet 'by a mile' in 2021 Defence Department competition

item.title: Pope: In Nicaea a message of unity for Christians, in Lebanon for peace
item.description:
At Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo XIV answers journalists’ questions outside Villa Barberini. He describes his upcoming apostolic journey to Türkiye and Lebanon as a trip marked by hope and peace. On Ukraine and the Middle East, he urges always seeking dialogue to end war. Regarding efforts to stop violence against women on the day dedicated to the issue, he says that mentalities must change beginning with the education of young people.

item.title: Pope Leo headed to Turkey and Lebanon for 1st trip abroad as leader of Catholic Church
item.description: Pope Leo will embark on his first trip outside Italy as the leader of the Catholic Church on Thursday, traveling to Turkey and Lebanon, where he is expected to make appeals for peace in the region and urge unity among long-divided Christian churches.

item.title: Voice of peace and hope: Pope Leo's visit to Türkiye and Lebanon
item.description:
The director of the Holy See Press Office presents Pope Leo XIV’s first apostolic journey that takes him to Türkiye and Lebanon, emphasising ecumenical commemoration, interreligious dialogue, and support for local Christian communities. The visit includes historic and symbolic encounters, meetings with civil and religious leaders, and gestures of solidarity amid regional challenges.

item.title: Global HIV response facing worst setback in decades, UNAIDS warns

item.title: Over 600 million children exposed to violence at home, UNICEF warns
item.description: More than one in four children globally – around 610 million – live with mothers who have experienced physical, emotional or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in the past year, making violence a part of their everyday lives, according to new data released by the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on Tuesday.

item.title: Doctrine of the Faith: Monogamy is not a limitation but a promise of the infinite
item.description:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The doctrinal Note Una caro. In Praise of Monogamy has been published, exploring the value of marriage as an “exclusive union and mutual belonging.” It highlights the importance of conjugal charity and attentiveness to the poor, and condemns all forms of violence, both physical and psychological. In an individualistic and consumerist age, young people must be educated to understand love as responsibility and trust in the other.

item.title: Blue Jays logo on display at Japan boxing match, without apparent MLB sign-off

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on Gaza, the West Bank and Lebanon
item.description: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. The session is likely to focus on safeguarding the truce, easing aid access restrictions and sustaining political momentum. With tensions also rising in the occupied West Bank and southern Lebanon, the meeting will test whether the Council can help stabilise the situation and keep alive a credible path towards Palestinian self-determination. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here. For in-depth meetings coverage, go here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council is meeting against the backdrop of Gaza’s fragile ceasefire, with ambassadors expected to urge Israel and Hamas to stick to their commitments amid renewed violence and deepening humanitarian needs. The session is likely to focus on safeguarding the truce, easing aid access restrictions and sustaining political momentum. With tensions also rising in the occupied West Bank and southern Lebanon, the meeting will test whether the Council can help stabilise the situation and keep alive a credible path towards Palestinian self-determination. item.title: US, Kyiv work on 'refined' peace plan to end Ukraine war
item.description: US and Ukrainian officials have sought to narrow the gaps between them over a plan to end the war in Ukraine, after agreeing to modify a US proposal that Kyiv and its European allies saw as a Kremlin wish list.
item.source:markdown: US and Ukrainian officials have sought to narrow the gaps between them over a plan to end the war in Ukraine, after agreeing to modify a US proposal that Kyiv and its European allies saw as a Kremlin wish list.

item.title: Three charged with criminal damage at Shannon Airport
item.description: Three people appeared before a special sitting of Ennis District Court last night charged with vandalising a US military aircraft at Shannon Airport in an incident that caused the airport to shut down for 30 minutes on Saturday morning.
item.source:markdown: Three people appeared before a special sitting of Ennis District Court last night charged with vandalising a US military aircraft at Shannon Airport in an incident that caused the airport to shut down for 30 minutes on Saturday morning.

item.title: 'Access to cash' law to come into force this week
item.description: A new law that requires financial institutions to ensure that an ATM is located within 10km of the vast majority of homes and businesses is set to come into force this week.
item.source:markdown: A new law that requires financial institutions to ensure that an ATM is located within 10km of the vast majority of homes and businesses is set to come into force this week.

item.title: Shoppers will spend at least €283 in Black Friday sales
item.description: Almost three-quarters of Irish consumers are planning to spend the same or less over the upcoming Black Friday weekend compared to last year, according to a new survey.
item.source:markdown: Almost three-quarters of Irish consumers are planning to spend the same or less over the upcoming Black Friday weekend compared to last year, according to a new survey.

item.title: Reaction to COP30 ranges from disappointment to support
item.description: Reaction to the COP30 agreement ranges from deep disappointment to qualified support.
item.source:markdown: Reaction to the COP30 agreement ranges from deep disappointment to qualified support.

item.title: Bolsonaro says paranoia made him tamper with monitor
item.description: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has said he experienced a medicine-induced "paranoia" that led him to tamper with his electronic ankle monitor, a document seen by Reuters showed, one day after the federal police took him into custody as a potential flight risk.
item.source:markdown: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has said he experienced a medicine-induced "paranoia" that led him to tamper with his electronic ankle monitor, a document seen by Reuters showed, one day after the federal police took him into custody as a potential flight risk.

item.title: Israel says Hezbollah leader killed in Beirut strike
item.description: Israel has killed militant group Hezbollah's top military official in an airstrike on a southern suburb of Beirut, the Israeli military said, despite a US-brokered truce a year ago.
item.source:markdown: Israel has killed militant group Hezbollah's top military official in an airstrike on a southern suburb of Beirut, the Israeli military said, despite a US-brokered truce a year ago.

item.title: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions couldn't be more urgent
item.description: The need to reduce or "mitigate" greenhouse gas emissions, to limit the rise in global temperatures could not be more urgent, writes George Lee.
item.source:markdown: The need to reduce or "mitigate" greenhouse gas emissions, to limit the rise in global temperatures could not be more urgent, writes George Lee.

item.title: Donegal nun shares 'anguish' after Nigeria kidnapping
item.description: A Donegal nun has spoken of her deep anguish and urged people around the world to pray for the release of the students and staff who were abducted from a school in Nigeria.
item.source:markdown: A Donegal nun has spoken of her deep anguish and urged people around the world to pray for the release of the students and staff who were abducted from a school in Nigeria.

item.title: Tributes to 'kind, gentle' woman who died after stabbing
item.description: Tributes have been paid to retired chemical engineer, Stella Gallagher, who died after she was stabbed near her home in Ballinlough in Cork city last Monday.
item.source:markdown: Tributes have been paid to retired chemical engineer, Stella Gallagher, who died after she was stabbed near her home in Ballinlough in Cork city last Monday.

item.title: Taxi drivers call for update in industry regulations
item.description: Irish taxi drivers are calling for regulations of the industry to be updated - which they claim do not keep pace with the rise of app-based dispatchers.
item.source:markdown: Irish taxi drivers are calling for regulations of the industry to be updated - which they claim do not keep pace with the rise of app-based dispatchers.

item.title: New immigration rules to consider welfare payments
item.description: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has confirmed that certain types of welfare payments, paid to people seeking Irish citizenship, will be taken into consideration as part of the application process.
item.source:markdown: Taoiseach Micheál Martin has confirmed that certain types of welfare payments, paid to people seeking Irish citizenship, will be taken into consideration as part of the application process.

item.title: Bolsonaro claims 'hallucinations' led the ex-Brazil president to tamper with ankle monitor
item.description: On his first full day in jail, former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro told a judge on Sunday he had violated his ankle monitoring the day before while under house arrest because of a nervous breakdown and hallucinations caused by a change in his medication.
item.source:markdown:
![A person is seen through the shutters of a window.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/58ca1250-4557-45fa-9e2f-b3e0e5dcd22a,1763921947142/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C152%2C2921%2C1643%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
On his first full day in jail, former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro told a judge on Sunday he had violated his ankle monitoring the day before while under house arrest because of a nervous breakdown and hallucinations caused by a change in his medication.

item.title: 50 children kidnapped from a Nigerian school escape
item.description: Fifty of the more than 300 children snatched by gunmen from a Catholic school in Nigeria have escaped their captors, a Christian group has said in a statement.

item.title: Pope Leo calls for the release of hostages in Nigeria and Cameroon
item.description:
After Mass on the Solemnity of Christ the King in St Peter's Square, Pope Leo makes a heartfelt appeal for the release of students and priests kidnapped in recent days in Nigeria and Cameroon.

item.title: Industry at the heart of international solutions: UN summit opens in Riyadh
item.description: Leaders from across the world are debating how industry can help tackle some of the world’s most urgent challenges – from climate change and food insecurity to the need for fairer supply chains – at the Global Industry Summit, which opened on Sunday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
item.source:markdown: Leaders from across the world are debating how industry can help tackle some of the world’s most urgent challenges – from climate change and food insecurity to the need for fairer supply chains – at the Global Industry Summit, which opened on Sunday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Malaria vaccine price cut set to protect 7 million more children by 2030
item.description: Vaccine alliance Gavi and children’s agency UNICEF have struck a new pricing deal that will sharply cut the cost of a key malaria vaccine and make it possible to protect nearly seven million additional children by 2030, the agencies announced on Sunday.
item.source:markdown: Vaccine alliance Gavi and children’s agency UNICEF have struck a new pricing deal that will sharply cut the cost of a key malaria vaccine and make it possible to protect nearly seven million additional children by 2030, the agencies announced on Sunday.

item.title: From milking stalls to mobile apps: UN-supported project powers rural revival in Indonesia
item.description: In the rolling hills of Indonesia’s West Java province, thousands of farmers are reaping tangible benefits from the digitization of their businesses and improved access to finance, thanks in part to a United Nations‑supported project.
item.source:markdown: In the rolling hills of Indonesia’s West Java province, thousands of farmers are reaping tangible benefits from the digitization of their businesses and improved access to finance, thanks in part to a United Nations‑supported project.

item.title: Pope Leo issues Apostolic Letter 'In unitate fidei' on Nicaea Anniversary
item.description:
Ahead of his upcoming Apostolic Journey to Türkiye, Pope Leo issues the Apostolic Letter 'In unitate fidei' on the 1700th Anniversary of the Council of Nicaea, broken down into 12 points, with the hope of "encouraging the whole Church to renew her enthusiasm for the profession of faith."

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: 50 schoolchildren escape captivity in Nigeria, 253 students and 12 teachers still being held
item.description: Fifty of the 303 schoolchildren abducted from a Catholic school in north-central Nigeria’s Niger state have escaped captivity and are now with their families, the school authority said Sunday, bringing relief to some distraught families after one of the largest school abductions in Nigeria’s history.
item.source:markdown:
![A man's hand places piles of newspapers.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/82733b54-401c-4175-bda3-cbac1fa79c16,1763910222685/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C354%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Fifty of the 303 schoolchildren abducted from a Catholic school in north-central Nigeria’s Niger state have escaped captivity and are now with their families, the school authority said Sunday, bringing relief to some distraught families after one of the largest school abductions in Nigeria’s history.

item.title: Pope Leo: Choirs are called to be a sign of the Church’s unity
item.description:
On the Jubilee of Choirs, Pope Leo XIV celebrates Mass, urging choristers to live their ministry as a sign of ecclesial unity, singing “in unison” as a people walking together in faith. He notes that liturgical music must foster communion, helping the whole Church journey forward.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
On the Jubilee of Choirs, Pope Leo XIV celebrates Mass, urging choristers to live their ministry as a sign of ecclesial unity, singing “in unison” as a people walking together in faith. He notes that liturgical music must foster communion, helping the whole Church journey forward.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-leo-xiv-jubilee-choirs-mass-ecclesial-unity-synodality.html)

item.title: Wood grain analysis reveals bass guitar's link to Queen
item.description: A painstaking exercise in matching the pattern of wood grain on an electric bass guitar to video footage of the band Queen has tripled the instrument's value as it comes up for auction.
item.source:markdown: A painstaking exercise in matching the pattern of wood grain on an electric bass guitar to video footage of the band Queen has tripled the instrument's value as it comes up for auction.

item.title: Slovenia holds vote on contested assisted dying law
item.description: Slovenians have begun voting in a new referendum that will determine if a law legalising assisted dying will be enforced or suspended, after critics mounted a campaign against the legislation.
item.source:markdown: Slovenians have begun voting in a new referendum that will determine if a law legalising assisted dying will be enforced or suspended, after critics mounted a campaign against the legislation.

item.title: Israel strikes Lebanon's capital killing top Hezbollah official, despite ceasefire
item.description: Israel carried out an airstrike on a southern Beirut suburb on Sunday, saying it killed Hezbollah’s chief of staff Haytham Tabtabai and warning the Iran-backed militant group not to rearm and rebuild a year after their latest war.

item.title: U.S., Ukraine tout 'updated and refined peace framework,' but details still scarce
item.description: The U.S. and Ukraine said they had created an "updated and refined peace framework" to end the war with Russia that apparently modified an earlier plan drafted by the Trump administration which Kyiv and its allies saw as too sympathetic to Moscow.

The U.S. and Ukraine said they had created an "updated and refined peace framework" to end the war with Russia that apparently modified an earlier plan drafted by the Trump administration which Kyiv and its allies saw as too sympathetic to Moscow.

item.title: Communities unite in darkest of weeks after Dundalk crash
item.description: It was as if an earthquake had struck the northeast, with the shockwaves felt in Louth, Cavan, and Monaghan. But the devastating impact also had the effect of solidifying these communities in their support for each other, writes Laura Hogan.

item.title: 'Too little, too late' - key points from UK Covid Inquiry
item.description: One of its headline findings is that 23,000 fewer people would have died in England during the first wave had the government introduced a lockdown one week earlier, writes Tommy Meskill.
item.source:markdown: One of its headline findings is that 23,000 fewer people would have died in England during the first wave had the government introduced a lockdown one week earlier, writes Tommy Meskill.

item.title: 'CPR is vital' - teenage swimmer in call over training
item.description: The family of a Co Laois teenager who suffered a cardiac arrest while on a swim training camp in Barcelona last summer say they believe CPR training should be made mandatory in secondary schools.
item.source:markdown: The family of a Co Laois teenager who suffered a cardiac arrest while on a swim training camp in Barcelona last summer say they believe CPR training should be made mandatory in secondary schools.

item.title: Girlbossing it: Kim Kardashian's billion dollar empire
item.description: Kim Kardashian may still be the butt of many jokes, but she's built an incredible business empire in spite – or maybe because – of that, writes Adam Maguire.

item.title: Vietnam flood death toll rises to 90, 12 others missing
item.description: The death toll from major flooding in Vietnam has risen to 90, with 12 people still missing, the environment ministry has said, after days of heavy rain and landslides.

item.title: Top US, Ukrainian officials hail 'good progress' in talks

item.title: 3 ways Canada and China can reset their relations in Trump's new trade world
item.description: As Canada starts to diversify its ties with other countries amidst an increasingly unpredictable and unreliable relationship with the U.S., its pivot toward China, in particular, will need to be strategic: the work must be done while balancing the risks and strengthening the country internally.

As Canada starts to diversify its ties with other countries amidst an increasingly unpredictable and unreliable relationship with the U.S., its pivot toward China, in particular, will need to be strategic: the work must be done while balancing the risks and strengthening the country internally.

item.title: G20 summit wraps up with agreement on debt burden
item.description: The G20 Summit in Johannesburg has wrapped up with agreement among world leaders to tackle the debt burden on developing countries, strengthen climate-related disaster response and increase financing for the green energy transition.
item.source:markdown: The G20 Summit in Johannesburg has wrapped up with agreement among world leaders to tackle the debt burden on developing countries, strengthen climate-related disaster response and increase financing for the green energy transition.
